Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Alkane Dehydrogenation Catalyzed by CCC-Pincer Complexes of Iridium
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Anthony Chianese of Colgate University, for the development of novel C-C-C based pincer type catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation reactions. The goal of this work is to construct structure-reactivity relationships for a variety of catalysts whose electronic properties have been fine tuned with appropriate ligand substitutions. The functionalization of alkanes to alpha-olefins is a reaction of exceptional value and impacts the fine chemicals and polymer synthesis fields.

Broader impacts of the research include the possibility of developing new alpha-olefins for novel polymer syntheses, and the potential for novel detergents and surfactants. For example, if an efficient catalyst is found with high selectivity that can use propylene as acceptor and yields terminal olefins, this could provide a major new route to these important building blocks. This research is ideal for an undergraduate institution, with students poised to learn organic and organometallic synthesis as well as a host of spectroscopic characterization methods. Professor Chianese is actively involved in outreach through the Colgate Summer Sport and Science Camp.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award funded a research project at in the laboratory of Professor Anthony Chianese at Colgate University, a predominantly undergraduate institution. The goal was to develop catalysts to selectively convert the cheap, abundant molecules obtained from crude petroleum into more useful, value-added products. Many of the materials and chemicals we use every day are derived almost entirely from petroleum, including plastics, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and advanced materials. As supplies of petroleum are limited, it is essential to use the resources we have as efficiently as possible.

To address this goal, a structurally diverse set of molecules based on the metal iridium was prepared, and each was tested for its ability to catalyze the removal of hydrogen from petroleum-derived hydrocarbons. Some of the iridium compounds were shown to be active catalysts for the desired chemical reaction, approaching the state of the art in the field in some cases. As previous studies have shown, a significant challenge is to selectively form one chemical product in cases where many products are possible: often, a less valuable mixture of products is formed. The most active catalyst we discovered did not selectively give one product, because it was also capable of catalyzing isomerization, where hydrogen atoms are moved from one position on the molecule to another. We devoted a substantial amount of effort during the grant period toward understanding exactly how this undesired reaction occurs, so that in the future we may design more selective catalysts.

All of the research for this project was conducted by undergraduate students in the PI’s laboratory at Colgate. Participation in undergraduate research, especially early in a student’s career, is increasingly recognized for its positive impacts on students. Undergraduates participated intellectually in all aspects of their research, including the conception of ideas, literature searching, the design and implementation of experiments, and their interpretation. As a result, undergraduate students in the Chianese group gained specific experience in the field of synthetic organometallic chemistry and developed a general perspective on how scientific knowledge is produced and disseminated. Ten undergradate students at Colgate contributed as co-authors on the three peer-reviewed publications that resulted from this project.
